Most controversially, BIT parties agree to be bound by dispute settlement provisions that are intended to ensure basic requirements of credible protection of property and contract rights, but which often result in foreign investors being granted greater security and better treatment than domestic inves- tors (Vandevelde, 1998). 3 The investor settlement procedure potentially involves considerable inter- ference in domestic policy, with practically any public policy being subject to challenge. 4 For individual hosts, there are likely to be benefits from being able to provide credible commitments to investors, which can lead to a competitive advantage as long as not all potential hosts have signed such treaties. The costs of BITs can generally be justified if the outcome of the BIT is to increase FDI inflows, and if these FDI inflows provide the benefits discussed above. The extent to which BITs actually encourage inward FDI is an empirical question. Empirical research addressing the impact of BITs on FDI flows 5 generally adopts one of two approaches. Some studies explain bilateral flows of FDI, usually estimating a gravity-type equation and includ- ing as one of its arguments a dummy variable for country-pairs that have a BIT. Others move away from a bilateral focus and examine whether countries that sign BITs see an increase in aggre- gate FDI inflows. While, in principle, BITs only protect investors from the signatory states to whom binding commitments have been made, their existence may also signal to potential investors elsewhere that this host country protects the interests of foreign investors more generally. If this is the case, then BITs encourage FDI inflows from both BIT partners and non-BIT sources. An example of the bilateral approach is Hallward-Driemeier (2003), who considers bilateral FDI flows from 20 OECD countries to 31 developing countries over the period 1980-2000. Controlling for country size and other country-specific factors, she finds no direct evidence that the existence of a BIT between a developed and a developing country increases the flow of FDI to the latter. If inter- actions between the BIT dummy and measures of institutional quality are included, however, the esti- mated coefficients are positive and often significant, a result implying that BITs are complementary to institutional quality. Perhaps BITs might seem credible in an environment of good institutional quality. Alternatively, as noted earlier, BITs might substitute for host institutional quality by provid- ing a certain standard of treatment to foreign investors where domestic institutions fail to do so. 6 An example of the aggregate approach is Tobin and Rose-Ackerman (2005) who examine 5 year averages of aggregate FDI inflows for 63 countries over the period 1980-2000. They find that a higher number of BITs (either in total or signed with a high-income country) lowers the share of global FDI a high-risk country receives, but raises the FDI share for low-risk countries, results consistent with a complementary relationship between BITs and institutional quality. Neu- mayer and Spess (2005) follow a similar approach, using aggregate FDI inflows to individual

The literature studying the effects of international agreements tends to be skewed towards studies of PTAs. Cipollina and Salvatici (2010) in their meta-analysis of PTAs include 85 studies, whereas Bellak (2013) in his more recent meta-analysis of the effects of BITs includes estimates from just 33 studies.

Related to the notion of heterogeneous effects of BITs, Salacuse and Sullivan (2005) also use bilateral FDI data and find that signing a BIT with the US is associated with significantly higher FDI inflows, but that signing a BIT with another OECD country has an insignificant impact on FDI inflows.

This variable is related to the cumulative number of BITs signed with developed countries (weighted by their share in total OECD FDI) and other explanatory variables. Their results indicate that a higher number of BITs raises FDI to developing countries, a result that is robust to changes in model specification, estimation technique and sample size. The authors also report some evidence suggesting that BITs might act as substitutes for good domestic institutional quality, although this result is not robust to alternative specifications of insti- tutional quality. 7 Whatever the approach adopted, the evidence from this literature is mixed. Some estimated coef- ficients are negative (e.g., Gil-Pareja, Llorca-Vivero, & Paniagua, 2013; Tobin & Rose-Ackerman, 2011); some are insignificant (e.g. Blonigen & Davies, 2004); and others are positive (e.g., Neu- mayer & Spess, 2005). Bellak (2013) summarises much of the empirical literature, undertaking a meta-analysis showing that 11% of the estimated coefficients on the BIT dummy are actually nega- tive (2% being significantly so), with 76% of the coefficients being positive and significant. In addi- tion, he finds that more recent studies have been more likely to find a negative coefficient and that the dispersion of the estimated coefficients has tended to increase over time. Bellak (2013) reports an un-weighted mean semi-elasticity of 17.6% in the papers he considers, but the standard deviation is found to be 37.4 with some estimates above 100% and others below À50%. An issue that was largely ignored in the early literature is the potential endogeneity of the BITs themselves. BIT formation was treated as exogenous, with country-pairs implicitly assumed to be randomly assigned into BITs, rather than self-selecting into them. Recent work by Bergstrand and Egger (2013) has shown that the economic fundamentals often found to determine FDI flows are also determinants of BIT membership. This can lead to a self-selection bias in the estimated impact of BITs on FDI flows. Some existing studies do control for this endogeneity, with Aisbett (2009), for example, using country-pair fixed effects in a model of bilateral FDI to control for self-selec- tion and finding that their inclusion reduces the coefficient on the BIT dummy and renders it insignificant. In contrast, Busse, K€ oniger, and Nunnenkamp (2010) and Kerner (2009) use an instrumental variables (IV) approach to control for endogeneity and still find a positive and signifi- cant impact of BITs on FDI inflows. Their data are not restricted to positive FDI flows. 8 This paper extends the existing literature in two main ways. First, we adopt an explicit differ- ence-in-difference (DiD) approach to identify a causal effect of the formation of new-BITs on bilat- eral FDI flows. The DiD approach allows for unobserved differences in treated and non-treated observations and thus controls for the potential self-selection of country-pairs in forming a BIT. In

The results of Myburgh and Paniagua (2016) suggest that foreign investors are less sensitive to host institutions if the host has ratified the Convention on Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards.

Recent research has delved deeper into the provisions of BITs. Berger, Busse, Nunnenkamp, and Roy (2013) consider the guarantees of market access provided by means of national treatment and most-favoured-nation treatment in the pre-estab- lishment phase; and credible commitments against discriminatory and discretionary treatment provided by international dis- pute settlement mechanisms in the postestablishment phase. They conclude that liberal admission rules promote bilateral FDI, but that dispute settlement provisions play only a minor role. In related work, Myburgh and Paniagua (2016) show that the effect of a host country increasing access to international commercial arbitration (by signing the Convention on Recogni- tion and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards) has a positive effect on FDI. This effect largely works through the size rather than the number of investment projects. Two recent papers have looked at the effects of disputes and international arbitration. Allee and Peinhardt (2011) show that FDI flows to a developing host country decline if it is brought before the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes. Aisbett, Busse, and Nunnenkamp (2016) consider the effects of disputes and arbitration settlements on FDI flows from BIT partner and non-partner countries. They find that BITs signed before any dispute involving the host country have a positive impact on bilateral FDI flows; that bilateral FDI flows from unprotected sources fall less than those from BIT-partners following a dispute and that the FDI boost a host receives from ratifying another BIT is smaller if it has been involved in a dispute.

this respect, Aisbett (2009) is the work most closely related to ours, as her use of country-pair and time fixed effects, as well as country-pair time-trends in some cases, creates a difference-in-differ- ence type estimator. She found, as we do, that once endogeneity had been controlled for there is no evidence of a statistically significant effect of BIT formation on FDI flows at the positive intensive margin. But her approach did not permit explicit consideration of the extensive and negative inten- sive margins. We also combine the DiD approach with matching to control for observed differences in characteristics between BIT and non-BIT country-pairs. Second, and most importantly, we distin- guish between the impact of BITs on existing FDI relationships between countries (i.e., the intensive margin) and their impact in creating new FDI relationships (i.e., the extensive margin), finding that the development of new FDI relationships and the reinvigoration of deteriorating FDI relationships are the important sources of the observed increase in FDI in response to BIT formation. The econo- metric approach that we adopt follows very closely the study of Egger, Egger, and Greenaway (2008), in which the authors use a DiD analysis of the effects of PTA formation on (intra-industry) trade based on narrow windows either side of the PTA signing. This approach has the advantage of allowing us to examine whether BITs work along both the extensive and intensive margins. The remainder of the paper is as follows: Section 2 describes our methodology; Section 3 dis- cusses the data and reports an initial descriptive analysis; Section 4 presents the main results of the paper, along with results from robustness tests; and Section 5 concludes.

As noted above, the approach we adopt borrows heavily from Egger et al. (2008), who used a DiD analysis to consider the causal effect of PTA formation on both the level and structure of trade. They argue that their DiD approach is able to control for all time-invariant unobserved effects and is most likely to lead to consistent estimates of the effect of PTAs after controlling for endogenous selection. In this section, we describe in detail the approach that we adopt, and how it allows us to both control for endogeneity due to self-selection and to consider the impact of BITs along the intensive and extensive margins. Difference-in-difference is one of a number of methods used in the treatment and evaluation liter- ature when assignment to treatment is not random and has been used increasingly to estimate the causal effects of policy changes. The method is particularly useful when the sample of untreated individuals may not provide an appropriate control group. In such a case, differences in the outcome between treated and untreated will reflect the effects of treatment, but also of other intrinsic differ- ences between the two groups. Difference-in-difference relies on the common trend assumption, which states that in the absence of treatment the average difference in the outcome variable between the two groups would have stayed roughly constant, meaning that the average difference in out- comes between the two groups prior to treatment can be used to approximate that part of the differ- ence in the average outcomes after the treatment that is due to intrinsic differences between the two groups. 9

While the DiD approach helps deal with the issue of self-selection, the possibility of reverse causality (i.e., that BITs are formed in response to high levels of FDI) remains. To get a sense of whether this might be an issue for our analysis, we calculated the average growth rate over the previous 8 years of FDI flows for country-pairs that formed a BIT and for those that did not (and were not already in a BIT) for each year over the period 1993-2003. While the growth rate of FDI in the previous 8 years was higher for new-BIT country-pairs than for non-BIT country-pairs in the majority of years (7 of 11), a simple t test reveals that these differences are not statistically significant.

In our analysis, we further have to account for the fact that we have more than a single treat- ment year, with different BITs being signed in different years. As discussed by Egger et al. (2008), we also need to ensure that the pre and post-treatment periods in our data are of equal length for both groups. We therefore construct a window around the years in which BIT formation occurs and compare the change in the (logged) average annual FDI flows between the groups. The control group for each year in which a BIT was formed are the country-pairs that did not already have a BIT and did not form one in the period over which the window was constructed. The trea- ted group in a particular year comprise the country-pairs that formed a BIT in that year. In more detail, the approach we adopt is as follows:

1. For each year, t, in our data set, we calculate the average of the FDI flow from source i to host j in the 5 years prior to that year, (PAFDI ijt ), as well as the average of FDI flows in the 5 years subsequent to our year of interest (SAFDI ijt ). We further calculate the average over the previous and subsequent 5 years of each of our (continuous) control variables (PAX ijt and SAX ijt respec- tively) that are described below, and define the variable BIT ijt = 1 if i and j formed a BIT in period t, and zero otherwise. 2. We then drop all observations for which a BIT was already in force prior to year t as well as observations for which a BIT was formed in the 5 years subsequent to year t, ensuring that our control group is not "contaminated" by country-pairs that had a BIT in the period of interest. While the DiD analysis allows for unobserved differences between the treated and untreated groups and requires a limited set of assumptions (i.e., the common trend assumption), there are good reasons to believe that finding a control group that is more similar to the treatment group may provide more accurate estimates of the effect of BITs. Egger et al. (2008), for example, find that the treatment effects of PTAs are downward biased by around 50% when relying on a simple DiD analysis. To consider this possibility, we adopt a second component of their work and com- bine DiD with propensity score matching to undertake a matched-DiD analysis. 13 Matching allows us to compare outcomes for treated and control observations that are similar in terms of their observable characteristics, and when combined with DiD potentially provides strong evidence of the causal effects of BITs on FDI flows by accounting for both observed and unobserved differ- ences between BIT members and non-members. By matching, we look to compare the outcomes (i.e., the change in FDI flows) of treated obser- vations (i.e., new-BIT country-pairs) with non-treated observations (i.e., non-BIT country-pairs) that are similar in terms of observable characteristics. 14 The general problem is to compare the change in the FDI variable for countries that enter into a BIT at time t with what the change would

It would also be possible to use the DiD estimator on each year separately. The drawbacks of such an approach include the relatively large number of estimates (i.e., one for each year) and the relatively small number of new-BIT events in each year.

Our use of the difference in the 5-year moving average of FDI as our dependent variable is likely to lead to serial correla- tion, which can lead to incorrect standard errors. To get around this issue, we cluster standard errors at the country-pair level in our analysis.
In this way, we control for the possibility that there may be differences in the change in FDI over time, due to business cycle effects for instance.

Matching econometrics has been used in labour economics to identify the effect of treatment for some time, and has become increasingly popular in other areas of economics. In the trade literature for example, matching has been employed to consider the causal effect of exporting on firm productivity (see for example, Girma, Greenaway, & Kneller, 2003) and to examine the impact of PTAs on international trade (see Baier & Bergstrand, 2009a; Egger et al., 2008).

There are alternative approaches. One is to use IV estimation, but this requires strong assumptions about functional form and typically requires the existence of instruments that are correlated with the selection indicators but not directly with the outcome. A second alternative is to control for unobserved heterogeneity through the use of country-pair fixed effects (e.g., Aisbett, 2009). Such a method only gives unbiased estimates if new-BIT membership is uncorrelated with the time-variant error, however. As mentioned by Aisbett (2009), the approach can also reduce the variability in the data, which can result in insignificant coefficients.

In order for this to be valid, however, we require that any differences in the changes in the FDI variable between BIT members and the non-BIT control group (other than those due to the presence of the BIT) are eliminated. We thus require a suitable control group. The basic idea behind matching is to find for each treated individual in the sample (e.g., for each country-pair entering into a BIT) an untreated individual (i.e., country-pair not entering a BIT) with similar characteristics. It is generally impractical to match on many explanatory variables. Similarity is therefore defined according to some metric that maps the vector of observables into a univariate variable. Two approaches are often adopted. The first is Mahalanobis matching, which involves weighting the coordinates of the covariates matrix by the inverse of that variable. The second is propensity score weighting which involves constructing the probability of treatment using a logit or probit equation. 15 Using one of these two approaches, it is possible to match a treated individual to either one or multiple untreated individuals. A comparison of the outcomes for the treated and the matched untreated groups then gives an estimate of the effect of the treatment. 16 In our analysis, we adopt the latter approach, estimating a probit model of the probability of forming a new-BIT. In addition to considering the impact of BITs on overall FDI flows, we use the information on whether FDI flows were zero or not in the previous 5 years to capture the separate effects of BITs on the extensive (EM) and intensive (IM) margins of FDI, further distinguishing between observa- tions along the intensive margin where flows were initially positive (IM + ) and those where flows were initially negative (IM À ). Few studies to date consider this issue, although Egger and Merlo (2012) report some evidence of the impact of BITs on the two margins using firm-level data for Germany. They base their arguments on recent models of heterogeneous firms (e.g., Melitz, 2003), with the signing of a BIT between two countries expected to lower the entry costs associated with FDI, thereby causing new firms to undertake FDI in the BIT partner (i.e., the extensive margin) and encouraging existing multinationals to increase production (i.e., the intensive margin). Using data on the foreign activity of German multinationals, they find evidence suggesting that BITs work along both margins, with the results suggesting that the signing of a BIT increases the num- ber of German firms active in a typical host by around 10%. Paniagua, Figueiredo, and Sapena (2015) decompose bilateral FDI flows into the number of investments projects and the average size of an investment in each flow. Using data on bilateral firm-level greenfield investments from 120 source countries to 161 host countries over the period 2003-12, they apply a quantile regression in a gravity framework. They conclude that a BIT can have a positive effect but only for average FDI levels above the median. 17 Given our focus on aggregate data, our hypothesis and argumentation is somewhat different. To the extent that BITs act as a means of substituting for weak domestic institutions in the host, then we would expect that multinational firms concerned about weak domestic institutions would not invest (or would withdraw previous investments) in that country without the protection of a BIT.
For more information on the difference between these estimators, see Wooldridge (2002) and the Stata help file for psmatch2.

Note that the ATT can be obtained from a weighted least squares regres- sion, where the weights for the untreated observations correspond to the weights used in the construction of the control group.
Myburgh and Paniagua (2016) use a similar approach and find a BIT reduces (raises) FDI levels below (above) the med- ian.

As such, we would expect that BITs by reassuring investors would lead to an expansion of FDI along the extensive margin and along the negative intensive margin (IM À ). Multinationals that choose to invest in a country without a BIT cannot be too concerned about the state of existing domestic institutions however, implying that the effects of a BIT along the positive intensive mar- gin may be muted. 18 We consider developments along the intensive and extensive margins by defining three separate BIT dummy variables, one for each of the margins:
BIT IM þ ¼ 1 if BIT ¼ 1 & PAFDI ijt [ 0; 0 otherwise
BIT IM À ¼ 1 if BIT ¼ 1 & PAFDI ijt \0; 0 otherwise
BIT EM ¼ 1 if BIT ¼ 1 & PAFDI ijt ¼ 0; 0 otherwise

Equation (1) is first estimated including a single BIT dummy capturing all BIT events, and then separately including only BIT events along one of the three margins. 19 In all cases, the set of con- trol group observations includes all non-BIT country-pairs, irrespective of the values of FDI in these country-pairs. Following the majority of the literature using gravity-type models, we wish to apply a log trans- formation to our FDI measures, as a way of reducing the skewness of the distribution and allowing the DiD estimator to provide an estimate of the percentage change in FDI due to BIT formation (i.e., a semi-elasticity). It also allows for a comparison of the meta-analysis results in Bellak (2013). Unfortunately, a routine application of the log transformation will exclude from considera- tion the large number of zero flows along with the negative values of FDI flows which involve instances of reverse or disinvestment. Furthermore, in our DiD analysis, where we use the differ- ence in the log of the average values of FDI between two time periods, all observations in which FDI changed from zero (or a negative value) to some positive number following the formation of a BIT would be excluded. 20 This would exclude precisely those cases where we suspect a BIT might have the greatest impact, as well as leading to the possibility of sample selection bias. Obviously, within a northern country some MNCs may choose to undertake FDI, while others choose not to. We may still expect a response along the intensive margin therefore, as the more risk averse MNCs respond to a BIT by undertaking FDI. It should also be noted that while the effect of a BIT on the overall level of FDI along the positive-intensive margin may be limited, it could be that the types of investment undertaken are affected. Javorcik (2004), for example, finds that weak intellectual property rights regimes deters foreign investors from investing in technology-intensive sectors, instead investing in projects focusing on distribution rather than local production. Our use of aggregate data prevents us from exploring such possibilities, however.

It should be kept in mind that as we are considering differences in 5-year averages, there is the possibility that a bilateral- pair is classed as being in a new FDI relationship in cases where an FDI relationship already existed, but not in the 5 years prior to the year of interest. The extensive margin captures the formation of new FDI relationships as well as the renewal of dormant FDI relationships therefore.

In the literature on the gravity equation attempts have recently been made to deal with a form of endogeneity that arises due to the presence of zero trade flows. Helpman, Melitz, and Rubinstein (2008) for example, propose a modified Heckman selection type model, while Santos Silva and Tenreyro (2006) suggest using a pseudo Poisson maximum likelihood model. It is not possible to use the former in our case. As we use the difference in FDI flows, there is no natural truncation at zero in our data set. It is further not possible to use the Poisson model in the case where negative values of the dependent vari- able are present.

In the analysis that follows we consider FDI flows from a sample of 22 OECD source countries (i.e., the "North") to a sample of up to 110 host countries (i.e., the "South"). 22 We consider unidirectional flows from the North to the South, with up to 2,420 observations per year. 23 Flows of FDI have grown more rapidly than trade for much of the last three decades. FDI inflows were around $400 million in 1995, $1.4 trillion in 2000 and, following slumps in the early 2000s and the recent global crisis, rose to $1.45 trillion in 2013 (UNCTAD, 2014). In our analysis, we use the OECD's Interna- tional Investment Statistics, which report data on bilateral FDI flows (inflows and outflows) for OECD reporting countries and a much larger sample of partner countries from 1982 onwards. Since we use data on the 5 years prior to and subsequent to a particular year in the DiD analysis, we are restricted to the years 1990-2006 for our regression analysis. In our analysis, we use data on deflated FDI outflows from the North to the South, with the values of current FDI reported in the OECD data set being deflated by the GDP deflator of the OECD source country. 24 Data on BITs are taken from UNCTAD's Investment Policy Hub (http://investmentpolicyhub. unctad.org/IIA), with data on ratified BITs being used in the subsequent analysis. 25 To give some indication of how important BITs have become in our data set, Figure 2 reports, by year, data on the frequency of new-BIT formation and the share of potential country-pairs (i.e., the maximum of 2,420) that are subject to a BIT. The figure shows that just 7% of country-pairs were subject to a BIT in 1985. Throughout the period considered, however, and during the 1990s and early 2000s in particular, a large number of new-BITs were agreed (an average of 44.5 per year during the 1990s and 41.8 over the period 2000-05). 26 By the end of the period therefore, around 40% of the coun- try-pairs were subject to a BIT. One implication of this figure is that country-pairs subject to BITs are not a unique, select group, although the share of country-pairs forming a new-BIT each period is on average low, being just 1.2%.

Overall, these descriptive results point to significant differences between the non and new-BIT country- pairs, which justifies the use of the DiD approach. 31 The DiD estimator relies on the assumption that the outcome variable follows a common trend in the pre-treatment period for the treated and control groups. One test of the common trend assumption is to run a regression of FDI flows on time fixed-effects, individual fixed-effects and interactions of the time fixed effects with the treatment (BIT) indicator (excluding the interaction for the period immediately prior to BIT formation). A test of whether the interaction terms for the pre-BIT period are jointly zero is then a test of a common trend (i.e., there are no significant differences in the difference in the intercept for treated and non-treated observations prior to treatment). We estimate such a model using the average values of FDI for non and new-BIT coun- try-pairs for 8-year windows each side of BIT formation. Combining data for each year between 1993 and 2003 gives us 352 observations, with 16 time periods (eight pre and eight post-BIT for- mation) and 22 individuals (i.e., an individual is considered the average of either the treated or untreated country-pairs in each of the 11 years). Estimating this regression results in coefficients on the interaction terms in the pre-BIT period that are neither jointly nor individually significant, thus providing evidence in favour of the common trend assumption. A simple alternative test of the common trend assumption is provided by visually comparing the trends in FDI prior to BIT formation. The dependent variable in the probit analysis is equal to one if a country-pair formed a BIT in time t and zero otherwise. 32 The set of explanatory variables we use are those described above, but rather than using the change between two periods we use the (average) values in the 5 years prior to year t, i.e., the initial values. Since we use the level rather than the change in these explanatory variables we are also able to include country-pair specific variables, such as distance, common language and a common border. The explanatory variables are therefore grounded in the theoretical model of Bergstrand and Egger (2007) and subsequently used by Bergstrand and Egger (2013). Our assumption is that once these characteristics have been controlled for, country-pairs are effectively randomly assigned to the BIT and non-BIT groups. We estimate the probit model for the full sample of observations, matching a BIT country-pair to any non-treated observation based on the set of explanatory variables, irrespective of the initial value of FDI in the non-treated country-pair (i.e., treated observations along a particular margin can be matched to non-treated observations across any margin). Before discussing the results it should be mentioned that a common critique of matching is that there may be some unobserved variables that affect selection into treatment. In other words, if we have two observationally equivalent country- pairs, and one signs a BIT while the other does not, can we assume that assignment to the BIT is random, rather than the result of an omitted variable that is correlated with FDI? A number of points negate this concern in our case. First, after matching on the propensity score we use DiD analysis, which itself controls for unobserved differences between the treated and control groups. Second, we have shown above in Figure 2 that country-pairs that join a BIT are not a specific, select group of observations. While in a typical year, the number of country-pairs joining a BIT is relatively small (around 1.2%), over the period of our study around 33% of country-pairs in our sample formed a BIT. Third, we use the theoretical model of Bergstrand and Egger (2007) to con- struct the counterfactual, which provides an appropriate framework for selecting the control group. Finally, we show that there is little evidence of statistically significant differences between the treatment and control groups for all the conditioning characteristics. This paper used a difference-in-difference methodology to estimate the causal effects of BIT forma- tion on FDI flows from OECD source countries to a large sample of developing host countries. When viewed collectively, we found that BIT formation had a positive and significant impact on FDI flows of somewhere between 50 and 95%. However, this aggregate outcome was shown to mask quite different experiences at the different margins. Where FDI flows were already positive prior to the BIT, we found no significant effect of BIT formation, a result consistent with the view that host institutions were already sufficiently strong so as to render the BIT largely superfluous. Where a BIT was shown to have strong, significant positive effects was where no FDI relationship was present prior to its formation (the extensive margin) or where an existing FDI relationship was disintegrating as evidenced by disinvestment prior to the BIT (the negative intensive margin). These outcomes are consistent with the view that host institutions were viewed as providing insufficient protection to foreign investors in these cases. These results were confirmed by our robustness tests. An obvious implication of this analysis is that policymakers should concentrate their efforts in signing BITs between countries at the negative intensive and extensive margins, although some caution is advised given that there may be other reasons why the relationships at these margins are what they are. A further implication is of the danger that new-BITs at the positive intensive margin may simply be sacrificing host national sovereignty (in the form of stronger protection of foreign investors) with little gain in the form of new net investment. From the BIT researcher's perspec- tive, our results illustrate the importance of identifying the negative intensive margin in the analy- sis. It is also important to retain the negative and zero flow observations in the analysis. In terms of future work, the inclusion of investment provisions in recent attempts at deep trade agree- ments among advanced nations suggests a similar examination of the effects of BIT agreements on North-North investment might be useful. So would a broadening of the focus beyond the bilateral, con- sidering the non-binary indices of the depth of BITs. It would further be useful to know the extent to which these estimates of the effects of BIT formation in promoting bilateral FDI actually represent "FDI diversion." It is not unlikely that at least some of this FDI would otherwise have gone to third parties.
